bibl.title: Memorandum from Philip Showalter Hench to Domingo Ramos, March 4, 1941

div1.p: Hench summarizes his research on the yellow fever commission and sends Ramos his report concerning the true site of Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Memorandum from Philip Showalter Hench to Domingo Ramos, March 4, 1941
div1.opener:
3154
March 4, 1941
To: His Excellency, Dr. Domingo Ramos, Minister of National Defense,
Government of Cuba, Havana, Cuba.
From: Dr. Philip S. Hench, Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minnesota.
Memorandum concerning the true site of “Camp Lazear”
where the United States Army Yellow Fever Board (Drs. Reed, Carroll, Agramonte
and Lazear) in 1900-1901 proved the truth of the concept of Dr. Carlos Finlay
of Havana regarding the mosquito transmission of yellow fever.
Your Excellency:
div1.p:
During part of his college career Dr. Jesse W. Lazear, the martyred member of the
United States Army Yellow Fever Board, attended Washington and Jefferson College, Wash-
ington, Pennsylvania. On October 26, 1940 this college dedicated a beautiful memorial
building to the memory of Dr. Lazear. In preparation for this dedication the President
of the College, Dr. Ralph Cooper Hutchison, asked me in 1937 to review the work of the
Board in order to give an address thereon at the dedication. I reviewed the official
and unofficial writings of the members of the Board and corresponded with certain sur-
vivors of the yellow fever experiments, notably Mr. John J. Moran of Havana, and Mr.
John R. Kissinger of Huntington, Indiana, the first two men to volunteer to receive
adequately controled experimental yellow fever.

In April, 1940 I visited Havana to meet Mr. Moran and to view the former sites of
Camp Columbia and Camp Lazear. Mr. Moran took me to the small plot of ground now owned
by the Cuban government, marked off by a fence and memorialized by a sign as the site of
Camp Lazear; this site is just across the La Playa railroad track from the rear of the
Military Hospital at Ciudad Militar. Because of certain observations to be noted herein
I concluded that the marked spot was not the true site of Camp Lazear. As a result of
the subsequent investigations of Mr. Moran and myself with the cooperation of Mr. Luis
Pogolotti, Havana engineer and real estate operator, we discovered (1) the true site of
Camp Lazear and (2) the remains of one of the two chief buildings in which the work at
Camp Lazear was done; we also discovered (3) what occurred at the site now falsely called
“Camp Lazear”, which occurrences formed the basis for the local tradition that resulted
in the erroneous location of the camp. But as will be seen the latter actually was a
fortunate mistake.

When I was in Havana I had the honor of presenting to you a brief outline of our
preliminary investigations. You asked me to transmit to you, for the Cuban Government,
a documented summary of these investigations so that the historical sites concerned
could be properly preserved, marked and memorialized. In the interim I have continued
my investigations and herewith I present you such documentary evidence as I have been able
to assemble to date. I plan to revisit Havana during the next month to conclude these
investigations and, if possible, to present a plan whereby I may be permitted to cooperate
remaining thereon. I would greatly appreciate knowing whether you expect to be in Havana
the last week in March or the first week in April, and whether I may have an appointment
to discuss briefly with you the details of the plan.
